dialogue: Look at the point at 1 on this number line. It shows 6/6. Why does 6/6 equal 1 whole?
prompt: Select the best explanation for why 6/6 = 1.

options.text: 6 parts out of 6 total—that's all of them, which is 1 whole
Because six sixths is more than five sixths
Because it's past zero on the number line

correct_answer.context: When all parts are present (6 out of 6), they make one complete whole

success_path_dialogue: Exactly. When you have all the parts, you have one whole.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Think about what happens when you have all the parts together.

Let's think about this more carefully. Look at the number line—it's divided into 6 equal parts. When a fraction has the same number on top and bottom, like 6/6, that means we have all the parts. What does having all the parts give us?

Let me walk you through this concept. The number line shows sixths—6 equal parts between 0 and 1. The fraction 6/6 means we have 6 parts out of a total of 6 parts. When we have all the parts—every single one of them—they make up one complete whole. That's why 6/6 equals 1. The answer is that 6 parts out of 6 total is all of them, which is 1 whole. This is true for any fraction where the numerator and denominator are the same—you have all the parts, so you have one whole.
